Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Dream Catcher: A High-Fidelity Baby Sleep Monitor
Award.AbstractNarration:
Sleep is a major problem for parents of young children. This is demonstrated by the large number of best-selling books on "sleep training" geared toward new parents, and by the numerous courses offered to new parents focusing on helping them get a better handle on their infant's sleep. But despite the attention given to educating parents about how to teach their children to sleep, getting a good night sleep remains one of the most anxiety-provoking aspects of parenting. There are a large number of baby monitors currently on the market, but none provide direct information about sleep. The majority of devices provide an audio monitor so that parents can hear whether their baby is crying. But sound is a poor proxy for sleep. The proposed project will solve this problem by developing the high-fidelity baby sleep monitor for use at home by parents.

This I-Corps team will develop a consumer product that will provide better and more direct information about sleep. The team will leverage recent developments in both hardware and software to make measuring and monitoring sleep simple and cost effective, so that parents will be able to monitor their infant's sleep. The team will develop a product that provides parents with useful information about their baby?s sleep by comparing measurements from their baby with the rest of the database. The team intends to apply the technology in a wide range of neurometric consumer products including self-monitoring of sleep throughout the lifespan, monitoring arousal/vigilance of professional drivers (e.g.,truck drivers) and pilots, and monitoring arousal/vigilance of security personnel (e.g.,TSA).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Parents lack a reliable way to monitor the timing and quality of their babies’ sleep. Sleep is an active state that is associated with distinct patterns of biological activity. To date, a baby sleep monitoring device that is a) easy to use; b) safe; c) delivers high fidelity signals; and d) interprets the data in a clear way to provide actionable information for parents, has been unavailable. The central goal of this NSF I-Corp project was to solve this problem by developing a high-fidelity baby sleep monitor for use at home by parents.

This I-Corp project aimed to first test our business model assumptions. This was accomplished by conducting multiple interviews with parents of young children and applying the I-Corps customer discovery methodology to evaluate the key assumptions. Secondly, this project was intended to develop a prototype of the baby sleep monitor according to evidence gathered during customer discovery.

The principal project objectives were to complete the I-Corps program with: a) a sound understanding of the Lean Startup methodology; b) validation of a new, evidence-based direction for the proposed business model; and c) a basic product prototype of the baby sleep monitor. The original goal was to follow up on the project with either an STTR/SBIR application and/or by raising an initial round of finance. Hence, the overall goal was to use the I-Corps work to establish early evidence of venture feasibility which may then be used to raise additional funding.

We participated in the I-Corp training program in Jan/Feb 2015. During this period, we developed a Business Model Canvas by working closely with the I-Corp teaching team and conducting extensive customer discovery (more than 300 interviews). We also developed an estimate of the target market size based on these interviews. Through these activities, and through consultation with the I-Corp teaching staff, we determined that we did not have a viable business model (i.e., we made a ‘no-go’ decision).

Through our activities during the I-Corp training program, we learned that there was significant interest in infant sleep data, even though our initial business model was not the basis of a viable business venture. In particular, we learned that there is a great deal of interest in developing a large dataset of baby sleep patterns which we (and others) could use to establish norms for human development of sleep and to assess children at risk for a variety of developmental disorders.

Based on what we learned from the I-Corps curriculum, we have begun a new research program about infant sleep (babysleepstudy.org). This research project is essentially the MVP that we emerged with from I-Corps. Parents are logging their infant's sleeping, eating, and diaper changes using the Baby Connect app, a popular baby-tracking app for Android, iPhone, iPad, and Windows Phone. Baby Connect (https://www.baby-connect.com) allows multiple caregivers to track information about feeding, diapers, sleep, mood, activities, and medications. The developers of the Baby Connect app are making the data available to us for infants enrolled in the study. We are recontacting parents annually to find out whether their child has been diagnosed with a developmental disorder. If so, we ask them to fill out a web form to specify the diagnosis.

We have acquired data from over 850 infants over the past 6 months, including 1.2 million sleep events, 2.1 million feedings, and 1.3 million diaper changes. The data are being analyzed to characterize developmental norms for sleep and digestion (i.e., a sleep and digestion chart analogous to the familiar height and weight chart), and to assess the statistical reliability of detecting outliers corresponding to infants who are later diagnosed with ASD or other developmental disorders. Some of the descriptive statistics include: the proportion of time/day infants spend sleeping as a function of age and how it is distributed over a 24-hour day, how eating and defecation are distributed throughout the 24-hour day as a function of age, at what age the circadian rhythm develops, the distribution of sleep bout durations during daytime and nighttime as a function of age, the distribution of intervals between sleep bouts, the distribution of intervals between eating and defecation, etc. We are also developing models to characterize infants’ sleep and digestion cycles (e.g., periodic functions that underlie changes between sleeping and waking states), and to characterize how infants’ cycles change with age.
